title: Peace on Earth, And Goodwill for Toys

body: PRESTON--Jane Elizabeth. 76, of Sarasota, FL, and North Fork, Long Island, died November 15th, 2005, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. She studied art under the
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PRESTON, JANE ELIZABETH

body: ''WELCOME to my fabulous rental,'' said Christine McKeon, a 38-year-old mother of three, a few weeks after moving into an imposing six-bedroom Victorian town house on one of Park Slope's grandest blocks. ''Look at my chandeliers!'' she said, rolling her eyes. ''Look at my dining room table!'' Ms. McKeon is a bare-feet-and-bluejeans kind of mom and,
title: HABITATS/Park Slope, Brooklyn; When a House Is Not Exactly a Home

title: Paid Notice: Deaths WILLETT, THORNTON WIN SLOW

body: The Gowanus Canal often stinks and is almost always spotted with slicks of oil. The streets alongside it are practically deserted, the silence broken by the rumble of concrete mixers and oil tankers or the screech of buzz saws. Graffiti abounds, and no one would use the word harmonious for the landscape, where ramshackle wood-frame and brick row
title: From Open Sewer to Open for Gentrification; Many Gowanus Residents Want Its Collar to Remain Blue

body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

body: Police officers descended on a Brooklyn neighborhood yesterday morning after a cafe owner said he had sold a cup of coffee to Peter Braunstein, the man investigators believe sexually assaulted a woman in her Chelsea apartment on Oct. 31. The man wore a long coat and something yellow underneath, the cafe owner, John Arena, said. He paid $2 for the
title: Sex Assault Suspect Came In for Coffee, Brooklyn Shop Owner Says

body: ON a recent Saturday afternoon, Bonnie Ralston and her husband, Mark Yarm, settled into a sofa at HomeCourt, a furniture store in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Atop a nearby table, in a 30-gallon aquarium, a little school of silvery killifish swayed and shimmered. A transparent shrimp danced across a bed of colorful pebbles. A blue crab batted at a golf
title: URBAN STUDIES/Thriving; Creatures From the Blueish Lagoon

body: The Southampton Publick House on Long Island is known for its excellent beers, made on the premises by Phil Markowski, the brew master, right. Now some are being sold by the bottle in New York City. One of them, the fruity, lightly citric, pale gold Double White Ale, is refreshing as an aperitif and delicious with Chinese food. The Imperial Baltic
title: FOOD STUFF; Southampton Beers Take the Reverse Commute

body: WHILE the narrow, slow-moving waterway in Brooklyn known as the Gowanus Canal has not been called ''Lavender Lake'' for some time, it remains an occasionally fetid and sludge-slicked thoroughfare. It is home to industrial businesses, infrequent boat visits and a growing contingent of marine life. Yet the canal, sandwiched between the real estate
title: LIVING IN/Gowanus, Brooklyn; Some See Venice; Some See a Canal

body: The resurgence of Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope and Williamsburg is well documented. In the borough's six million square feet of Class A office
title: SQUARE FEET; Towers Grow in Downtown Brooklyn

title: Lights Out

body: Investigators were still looking for a man who rents a Brooklyn apartment where the police found the bodies of two women on Friday morning, the authorities said yesterday. The man, identified as Antoine Twitty, 40, who served time in prison for attempted robbery and was described by neighbors as peculiar but friendly, has apparently not returned to
title: Man Sought After 2 Bodies Found in Home

body: THERE are 18 precious days until the spelling bee final, and Josh Malamy will not waste a single one. He is boning up on Latin and Greek roots and studying the 794 pages of Scripps National Spelling Bee word lists on Spellingbee.com. Among the obscure words he recently memorized were ''chrysochlorous'' (a greenish-gold color) and ''choumoellier''
title: The Night Life of Bees

body: While plenty of celebrities boast of their eco-friendly Priuses, there are some alpha A-listers who would rather accessorize with a bolt-action rifle. The British shoot-'em-up director Guy Ritchie has taken aim at everything from wild boar to clay pigeons. Kurt Russell tracks game and then donates his quarry to charity. And the N.R.A. rocker Ted
title: The Mantry; Killing Time

body: BROOKLYN should need no introduction: ancestors of as many as one in four Americans are said to have once called it home. But New York's most populous borough -- with about 2.5 million residents representing more than 90 ethnic groups -- has always been shadowed by its glamorous neighbor across the East River. Thriving a century ago, Brooklyn fell
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: As much of upper Brooklyn continues to meld into one enormous restaurant row, it can be difficult for established borough restaurants to decide where to open a second location. Dumbo? Williamsburg? Clinton Hill? How about Bushwick or Brownsville? The owners of Tuk Tuk on Smith Street in Cobble Hill, at four years old a neighborhood standby,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; For a Restaurant in the Mainstream, A Cruise Into Uncharted Waters

body: ONE evening four years ago Jennifer Thompson decided at the last minute to go to a cycling class at New York Sports Club. She had just joined the gym and was unfamiliar with the instructors at the Cobble Hill branch in Brooklyn, so she was surprised when an overweight woman hopped on the bike at the head of the room. ''I thought, that's the
title: New Breed of Trainers Are Proving Fat Is Fit

body: Over the Bounding Pond Q. Recently I passed the Central Park boat pond and noticed that all the model sailboats were guided by control boxes operated by youngsters on shore. title: F. Y. I.

body: The shoppers and young families strolling along Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can normally slurp their iced coffees, nosh on bagels and French pastries and browse for books far from the tumultuous politics of City Hall. But now it seems they cannot escape the mayoral candidates and their campaign workers prospecting for votes, as
title: Mayoral Rivals Fight for Turf in Brownstone Brooklyn

body: The New York State Regents examinations are for the most part well-administered and, in general, immune from wholesale fraud. But a blatant case of test tampering at a Brooklyn high school that took years to uncover suggests that state and city officials can still do more to protect the integrity of the testing process. New procedures that shield
title: Fraud in the Schools

body: State officials approved a draft plan yesterday for an 85-acre waterfront park near Downtown Brooklyn that would include playing fields, marinas, restaurants and offices, and 1,200 units of luxury housing. The proposed plan for a 1.3-mile shoreline park stretching from the Manhattan Bridge to Cobble Hill is an important step forward in a
title: Agency Adopts Park Plan For Brooklyn Waterfront

author: This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: PLOT: a used-book store's battle to stay afloat. Chief characters: two women who love literature, wanted to do something more creative than tending bar and waiting on tables, and scraped together savings and loans to create the store. Setting: a Brooklyn waterfront area that they love. Genre: nonfiction romance turned nonfiction suspense. ''I think
title: HOME FRONT; New Hopes for a Store Selling Used Books

body: LATE on the morning of Feb. 10, 2004, Philip Nobile convened his class in political law at the Cobble Hill School of American Studies and started a lesson on the Constitution's system of checks and balances. In addition to the 24 students in the room, Mr. Nobile had another listener, the school's assistant principal of humanities, Theresa Capra.
title: ON EDUCATION; In Exposing a Grading Scandal, Harsh Lessons Are Learned

Now, with Steven Ng and Sam Wong, he has opened Little Bistro, 158 Court Street (Pacific
title: FOOD STUFF; Off the Menu

Frank Carey High School in Franklin Square, on Long Island, saying she wanted to devote herself to clearing her name. According to a report last month by an
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Franklin Square: Teacher In Inquiry Quits

body: A former assistant principal in Brooklyn, who resigned last year while under investigation for allegations that she directed widespread cheating on the Regents exams, was hired as the head of the social studies department at a Long Island high school where she was again in charge of grading Regents exams this year. The former assistant principal,
title: Teacher in Regents Inquiry Got Job in School on L.I.

body: A Brooklyn high school principal covered up a widespread effort to inflate grades on the Regents exams in social studies in 2002 and 2003, education officials said yesterday, and he will face termination. The principal, Lennel George of the Cobble Hill School of American Studies, was removed this week after a 14-month investigation involving state
title: Principal Hid Fraud on Tests In Brooklyn, Officials Say

body: To the Editor: It irritates me when young adults act as if their discovery of Brooklyn is tantamount to Brigadoon. It wasn't always that way. I was born in Williamsburg, the oldest of a Jewish immigrant family crowded together with others in a decrepit tenement. Although our sense of the city extended little farther than the Williamsburg Bridge,
title: Fled, Then Returned

title: Priced Out, Again

body: WHEN Gary Rabin closed on a 38-foot-wide New York City town house this month, he happily acknowledged that his new home's girth would make him the envy of the tony town-house set. He had started off in 2003 with a 19.6-foot-wide brownstone on a quiet Greenwich Village block -- wide enough by any conventional brownstone standards. There was no need
title: The Quest for a Wide Town House

body: THE leafy, sleepy Midwood neighborhood of Brooklyn is as green, clean and quiet as it was in the late 1950's, when Willa Gelber was a teenager and itchy for more sophisticated urban pleasures. Her family lived in that Midwood archetype, a large 1950's stucco two-family house with a front porch, a backyard and a finished basement, along with a dark
title: HABITATS/Midwood, Brooklyn; Discovering You Can Go Home Again

title: WORD FOR WORD; A Smattering of the City's Eight Million Stories

body: To the Editor: Was the move out of the city worth it? (''Is It Worth It?'' May 22.) I was a lifelong Manhattanite. We were frankly ill-prepared for having three children in rapid succession, and succumbed to the
title: Not a Yes or No Answer

body: A flier on a lamppost is hope's smudged fingerprint, desperation's encore. It is a tiny hand extended, reaching into the vastness of New York City for connections, answers, work, validation or help. In Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the molded lampposts carry word of someone's stoop sale, an opera for kids, a block party. Karen the Spanish Tutor wants
title: Fliers Tell the Tale: Lost But Maybe Not Gone

body: NETCHINSKY--Rhoda (Levin), 84, artist and political activist, member of the Art Students League, on May 22 in Brooklyn. Deeply loved by friends and family: her sister, Mimi Leipzig, daughters, Jill Netchinsky - Toussaint and Suzy D'Angelo, grandchildren, Joseph, Jennifer, Antoinette and Jonah, and three great - granddaughters. title: Paid Notice: Deaths NETCHINSKY, RHODA (LEVIN)

body: PITY the poor inspectors, who have to walk with blinders on. The city might be riddled with violations of the laws protecting historic buildings. title: SQUARE FEET; On the Waterfront in Brooklyn, an Enclave Regains Its Energy

body: Reported hate crimes against Muslims in the United States increased by more than 50 percent last year, with New York State ranking second nationally in the number of bias cases, according to a study released yesterday by the Council on American-Islamic Relations, an Islamic advocacy group in Washington. title: Study by Muslim Group Says Bias Crimes Up 50% in 2004

title: African Orphans Give Their All, in Song, for New Home

title: TURF; Condos Break Sound Barrier

body: In fewer than 20 words, the songwriter Michael Smith once neatly summarized many basic tenets of the American Catholic school experience, as transmitted by his fifth grade teacher, Sister Clarissa. title: Once Mighty, Catholic Schools Find Status Is Diminished

body: Through the eyes of a developer, the building at 275 Atlantic Avenue has a lot going for it. It is 11 stories tall and centrally located. And if you strip away the tall wire fences and the cages that cover the windows, it's not a bad piece of modern architecture, either. The building is the Brooklyn House of Detention, which has been closed since
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; In Case a Jail Closes: Pursuing Ideas for a Gentler Future

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK/GOWANUS; In an Industrial Neighborhood, Grim Signs That Families Live There

The vision of strolling or whizzing past bustling parks and quaint row houses or taking in panoramic views of the Manhattan skyline,
title: Long, Green Pathway Planned Along Brooklyn Waterfront

body: LAST April, Maria Andriano offered $520,000 for a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side that was listed at $465,000, as well as a 50 percent down payment. She lost out to a higher bidder. Because Ms. Andriano, a public relations executive, was up against several other prospective buyers, she was given only one chance to submit her ultimate
title: ASSETS; Calculating a 'Best and Final' Offer

body: SANDWICHED between Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Clinton Hill in Brooklyn might just be the quintessence of urban living in New York City. It is affluent and not so, seedy and grand, ethnically diverse, a magnet for artists, musicians and filmmakers, and so rich in architectural style that even now, with escalating property prices, a new
title: LIVING IN/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; Into the Big Leagues, With Prices to Match

body: CAPOLARELLO--Grace Auditore, passed away on Monday evening, January 3, 2005. at the age of 84. The wake will be held on Friday, January 7, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at the corner of E. 81st St. from 4-7:30pm. She'll be laid to rest beside her husband Carmelo, and her son Dominick at 1:30pm on Saturday, January 8th at
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CAPOLARELLO, GRACE AUDITORE

body: Rebecca Nienkamper has a holiday role to play, and she does it with no regrets. title: Peace on Earth, And Goodwill for Toys

body: PRESTON--Jane Elizabeth. 76, of Sarasota, FL, and North Fork, Long Island, died November 15th, 2005, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. She studied art under the
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PRESTON, JANE ELIZABETH

body: ''WELCOME to my fabulous rental,'' said Christine McKeon, a 38-year-old mother of three, a few weeks after moving into an imposing six-bedroom Victorian town house on one of Park Slope's grandest blocks. ''Look at my chandeliers!'' she said, rolling her eyes. ''Look at my dining room table!'' Ms. McKeon is a bare-feet-and-bluejeans kind of mom and,
title: HABITATS/Park Slope, Brooklyn; When a House Is Not Exactly a Home

body: WILLETT -- Thornton Win slow, of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Died peacefully on November 25, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Martha Leah Miller Willett. title: Paid Notice: Deaths WILLETT, THORNTON WIN SLOW

body: The Gowanus Canal often stinks and is almost always spotted with slicks of oil. The streets alongside it are practically deserted, the silence broken by the rumble of concrete mixers and oil tankers or the screech of buzz saws. Graffiti abounds, and no one would use the word harmonious for the landscape, where ramshackle wood-frame and brick row
title: From Open Sewer to Open for Gentrification; Many Gowanus Residents Want Its Collar to Remain Blue

body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

body: Police officers descended on a Brooklyn neighborhood yesterday morning after a cafe owner said he had sold a cup of coffee to Peter Braunstein, the man investigators believe sexually assaulted a woman in her Chelsea apartment on Oct. 31. The man wore a long coat and something yellow underneath, the cafe owner, John Arena, said. He paid $2 for the
title: Sex Assault Suspect Came In for Coffee, Brooklyn Shop Owner Says

body: ON a recent Saturday afternoon, Bonnie Ralston and her husband, Mark Yarm, settled into a sofa at HomeCourt, a furniture store in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Atop a nearby table, in a 30-gallon aquarium, a little school of silvery killifish swayed and shimmered. A transparent shrimp danced across a bed of colorful pebbles. A blue crab batted at a golf
title: URBAN STUDIES/Thriving; Creatures From the Blueish Lagoon

body: The Southampton Publick House on Long Island is known for its excellent beers, made on the premises by Phil Markowski, the brew master, right. Now some are being sold by the bottle in New York City. One of them, the fruity, lightly citric, pale gold Double White Ale, is refreshing as an aperitif and delicious with Chinese food. The Imperial Baltic
title: FOOD STUFF; Southampton Beers Take the Reverse Commute

body: WHILE the narrow, slow-moving waterway in Brooklyn known as the Gowanus Canal has not been called ''Lavender Lake'' for some time, it remains an occasionally fetid and sludge-slicked thoroughfare. It is home to industrial businesses, infrequent boat visits and a growing contingent of marine life. Yet the canal, sandwiched between the real estate
title: LIVING IN/Gowanus, Brooklyn; Some See Venice; Some See a Canal

body: The resurgence of Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope and Williamsburg is well documented. But what is not as widely known is how well the downtown business district is doing, despite a still somewhat dog-eared appearance. What is more, the area is on the verge of a major transformation. In the borough's six million square feet of Class A office
title: SQUARE FEET; Towers Grow in Downtown Brooklyn

What you say What you gonna doooooo -- They gonna close the hospital. A smiling figure in a black sweatshirt called out to him. ''Hey, you better have
title: Lights Out

body: Investigators were still looking for a man who rents a Brooklyn apartment where the police found the bodies of two women on Friday morning, the authorities said yesterday. The man, identified as Antoine Twitty, 40, who served time in prison for attempted robbery and was described by neighbors as peculiar but friendly, has apparently not returned to
title: Man Sought After 2 Bodies Found in Home

body: THERE are 18 precious days until the spelling bee final, and Josh Malamy will not waste a single one. He is boning up on Latin and Greek roots and studying the 794 pages of Scripps National Spelling Bee word lists on Spellingbee.com. Among the obscure words he recently memorized were ''chrysochlorous'' (a greenish-gold color) and ''choumoellier''
title: The Night Life of Bees

body: While plenty of celebrities boast of their eco-friendly Priuses, there are some alpha A-listers who would rather accessorize with a bolt-action rifle. The British shoot-'em-up director Guy Ritchie has taken aim at everything from wild boar to clay pigeons. Kurt Russell tracks game and then donates his quarry to charity. And the N.R.A. rocker Ted
title: The Mantry; Killing Time

body: BROOKLYN should need no introduction: ancestors of as many as one in four Americans are said to have once called it home. But New York's most populous borough -- with about 2.5 million residents representing more than 90 ethnic groups -- has always been shadowed by its glamorous neighbor across the East River. Thriving a century ago, Brooklyn fell
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: As much of upper Brooklyn continues to meld into one enormous restaurant row, it can be difficult for established borough restaurants to decide where to open a second location. Dumbo? Williamsburg? Clinton Hill? How about Bushwick or Brownsville? The owners of Tuk Tuk on Smith Street in Cobble Hill, at four years old a neighborhood standby,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; For a Restaurant in the Mainstream, A Cruise Into Uncharted Waters

body: ONE evening four years ago Jennifer Thompson decided at the last minute to go to a cycling class at New York Sports Club. She had just joined the gym and was unfamiliar with the instructors at the Cobble Hill branch in Brooklyn, so she was surprised when an overweight woman hopped on the bike at the head of the room. ''I thought, that's the
title: New Breed of Trainers Are Proving Fat Is Fit

body: Over the Bounding Pond Q. Recently I passed the Central Park boat pond and noticed that all the model sailboats were guided by control boxes operated by youngsters on shore. In the distance I noticed a vendor with a cart full of the same model boats, which he was apparently renting to would-be skippers. Does that mean that children can no longer
title: F. Y. I.

body: The shoppers and young families strolling along Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can normally slurp their iced coffees, nosh on bagels and French pastries and browse for books far from the tumultuous politics of City Hall. But now it seems they cannot escape the mayoral candidates and their campaign workers prospecting for votes, as
title: Mayoral Rivals Fight for Turf in Brownstone Brooklyn

body: The New York State Regents examinations are for the most part well-administered and, in general, immune from wholesale fraud. But a blatant case of test tampering at a Brooklyn high school that took years to uncover suggests that state and city officials can still do more to protect the integrity of the testing process. New procedures that shield
title: Fraud in the Schools

body: State officials approved a draft plan yesterday for an 85-acre waterfront park near Downtown Brooklyn that would include playing fields, marinas, restaurants and offices, and 1,200 units of luxury housing. The proposed plan for a 1.3-mile shoreline park stretching from the Manhattan Bridge to Cobble Hill is an important step forward in a
title: Agency Adopts Park Plan For Brooklyn Waterfront

author: This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: PLOT: a used-book store's battle to stay afloat. Chief characters: two women who love literature, wanted to do something more creative than tending bar and waiting on tables, and scraped together savings and loans to create the store. Setting: a Brooklyn waterfront area that they love. Genre: nonfiction romance turned nonfiction suspense. ''I think
title: HOME FRONT; New Hopes for a Store Selling Used Books

body: LATE on the morning of Feb. 10, 2004, Philip Nobile convened his class in political law at the Cobble Hill School of American Studies and started a lesson on the Constitution's system of checks and balances. In addition to the 24 students in the room, Mr. Nobile had another listener, the school's assistant principal of humanities, Theresa Capra.
title: ON EDUCATION; In Exposing a Grading Scandal, Harsh Lessons Are Learned

body: Chris Cheung, below, closed Tiger Blossom, a showcase on the Bowery for his inventive Chinese cooking, after 9/11 hurt business. The chef, who had worked at Jean Georges and Ruby Foo's, went on to cook at Rain in Manhattan and Long Tan in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Now, with Steven Ng and Sam Wong, he has opened Little Bistro, 158 Court Street (Pacific
title: FOOD STUFF; Off the Menu

Frank Carey High School in Franklin Square, on Long Island, saying she wanted to devote herself to clearing her name. According to a report last month by an
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Franklin Square: Teacher In Inquiry Quits

body: A former assistant principal in Brooklyn, who resigned last year while under investigation for allegations that she directed widespread cheating on the Regents exams, was hired as the head of the social studies department at a Long Island high school where she was again in charge of grading Regents exams this year. The former assistant principal,
title: Teacher in Regents Inquiry Got Job in School on L.I.

body: A Brooklyn high school principal covered up a widespread effort to inflate grades on the Regents exams in social studies in 2002 and 2003, education officials said yesterday, and he will face termination. The principal, Lennel George of the Cobble Hill School of American Studies, was removed this week after a 14-month investigation involving state
title: Principal Hid Fraud on Tests In Brooklyn, Officials Say

body: To the Editor: It irritates me when young adults act as if their discovery of Brooklyn is tantamount to Brigadoon. It wasn't always that way. I was born in Williamsburg, the oldest of a Jewish immigrant family crowded together with others in a decrepit tenement. Although our sense of the city extended little farther than the Williamsburg Bridge,
title: Fled, Then Returned

title: Priced Out, Again

I'm not much of an architect or a decorator, but she did it something
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; The Day When Back in the Day Ended

body: WHEN Gary Rabin closed on a 38-foot-wide New York City town house this month, he happily acknowledged that his new home's girth would make him the envy of the tony town-house set. He had started off in 2003 with a 19.6-foot-wide brownstone on a quiet Greenwich Village block -- wide enough by any conventional brownstone standards. There was no need
title: The Quest for a Wide Town House

body: THE leafy, sleepy Midwood neighborhood of Brooklyn is as green, clean and quiet as it was in the late 1950's, when Willa Gelber was a teenager and itchy for more sophisticated urban pleasures. Her family lived in that Midwood archetype, a large 1950's stucco two-family house with a front porch, a backyard and a finished basement, along with a dark
title: HABITATS/Midwood, Brooklyn; Discovering You Can Go Home Again

title: WORD FOR WORD; A Smattering of the City's Eight Million Stories

body: To the Editor: Was the move out of the city worth it? (''Is It Worth It?'' May 22.) I was a lifelong Manhattanite. I married for the first time at the relatively late age of 37 and moved with my new husband to a brownstone in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. We were frankly ill-prepared for having three children in rapid succession, and succumbed to the
title: Not a Yes or No Answer

body: A flier on a lamppost is hope's smudged fingerprint, desperation's encore. It is a tiny hand extended, reaching into the vastness of New York City for connections, answers, work, validation or help. In Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the molded lampposts carry word of someone's stoop sale, an opera for kids, a block party. Karen the Spanish Tutor wants
title: Fliers Tell the Tale: Lost But Maybe Not Gone

body: NETCHINSKY--Rhoda (Levin), 84, artist and political activist, member of the Art Students League, on May 22 in Brooklyn. Deeply loved by friends and family: her sister, Mimi Leipzig, daughters, Jill Netchinsky - Toussaint and Suzy D'Angelo, grandchildren, Joseph, Jennifer, Antoinette and Jonah, and three great - granddaughters. title: Paid Notice: Deaths NETCHINSKY, RHODA (LEVIN)

body: PITY the poor inspectors, who have to walk with blinders on. The city might be riddled with violations of the laws protecting historic buildings. title: SQUARE FEET; On the Waterfront in Brooklyn, an Enclave Regains Its Energy

body: Reported hate crimes against Muslims in the United States increased by more than 50 percent last year, with New York State ranking second nationally in the number of bias cases, according to a study released yesterday by the Council on American-Islamic Relations, an Islamic advocacy group in Washington. title: Study by Muslim Group Says Bias Crimes Up 50% in 2004

title: African Orphans Give Their All, in Song, for New Home

body: In fewer than 20 words, the songwriter Michael Smith once neatly summarized many basic tenets of the American Catholic school experience, as transmitted by his fifth grade teacher, Sister Clarissa. She was 11 feet tall, Mr. Smith reported, and when she wrote on the blackboard, not even the chalk dared to squeak. He sang: Sister Clarissa believes in
title: Once Mighty, Catholic Schools Find Status Is Diminished

body: Through the eyes of a developer, the building at 275 Atlantic Avenue has a lot going for it. It is 11 stories tall and centrally located. And if you strip away the tall wire fences and the cages that cover the windows, it's not a bad piece of modern architecture, either. The building is the Brooklyn House of Detention, which has been closed since
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; In Case a Jail Closes: Pursuing Ideas for a Gentler Future

body: The memorials are still there, affixed to lampposts and fences along the Gowanus-Red Hook corridor in South Brooklyn. Stuffed animals and religious figurines remain at the busy intersection of Third Avenue and Ninth Street in Gowanus, where Juan Estrada, 10, and Victor Flores, 11, were killed by a commercial truck a year ago this Wednesday. At
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK/GOWANUS; In an Industrial Neighborhood, Grim Signs That Families Live There

body: Pedestrians and cyclists, limited only by their own hamstrings and quadriceps, could one day travel 22 miles along a waterfront greenway from North Brooklyn to Coney Island, under a plan to be unveiled today. The vision of strolling or whizzing past bustling parks and quaint row houses or taking in panoramic views of the Manhattan skyline,
title: Long, Green Pathway Planned Along Brooklyn Waterfront

body: LAST April, Maria Andriano offered $520,000 for a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side that was listed at $465,000, as well as a 50 percent down payment. She lost out to a higher bidder. Because Ms. Andriano, a public relations executive, was up against several other prospective buyers, she was given only one chance to submit her ultimate
title: ASSETS; Calculating a 'Best and Final' Offer

body: SANDWICHED between Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Clinton Hill in Brooklyn might just be the quintessence of urban living in New York City. It is affluent and not so, seedy and grand, ethnically diverse, a magnet for artists, musicians and filmmakers, and so rich in architectural style that even now, with escalating property prices, a new
title: LIVING IN/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; Into the Big Leagues, With Prices to Match

body: CAPOLARELLO--Grace Auditore, passed away on Monday evening, January 3, 2005. at the age of 84. The wake will be held on Friday, January 7, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at the corner of E. 81st St. from 4-7:30pm. She'll be laid to rest beside her husband Carmelo, and her son Dominick at 1:30pm on Saturday, January 8th at
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CAPOLARELLO, GRACE AUDITORE
